Name: dong ling cao
冬凌草
冰凌草
Biological: Rabdosia rubescens (Hemsl.) S.Y. Wu et Hsuen
Other name: bing ling cao (冰凌草), meaning 'ice grass' because of the portions of stems near the ground are frozen during winter.
sui mi ya (碎米亞), academically called in Chinese

Geography: China: mainly in Henan province and areas south of Yellow River Valley.
Qi County, along both banks of the Qi River, Henan province (production area).
Maladies Treated: Inflammation and swelling of the tonsils
Chronic inflammation of the pelvic area
Medical Function: Remove blood stasis and relieve swelling
Dosage:
30 to 60 g per day for internal use.
No established amount for external use. Use accordingly.
Research:
Its active ingredients rubescensine A (C20H28O6; molecular weight 364.42) and rubescensine B can inhibit the synthesis of deoxyribonucleic acid and protein of cancer cells. They showed inhibition of Ehrlich-Ascites tumors, sarcoma180 and esophageal carcinoma in laboratory animals.

Modern research notes relieving esophagismus induced by acetylcholine.
Notes: This herb was not listed in herbal dictionaries of previous dynasties. It was made public from the folk medicine of the district of Qi, Henan province of China in 1972 and in 1977 it was listed in the Medical Dictionary of the Republic of China (中華人民共和國藥典).
Chemical Ingredients: Stems and leaves: contain volatile (vaporizing) oil.
Stems and leaves volatile oil component: α-Pinene (α-蒎烯) 1%
Stems and leaves volatile oil component: β-Pinene (β-蒎烯) 0.16～1%
Stems and leaves volatile oil component: Limonene (擰檬烯) 0.16%
Stems and leaves volatile oil component: 1.8-Cineole (1.8-桉油素) 0.33%
Stems and leaves volatile oil component: P-Cymene (對-聚傘花素) 0.16%
Stems and leaves volatile oil component: Nonaldehyde (壬 醛) 1.33%
Stems and leaves volatile oil component: Decanal (癸醛) 1%b
Stems and leaves volatile oil component: β-Elemene (β-攬香烯) 20.23%
Stems and leaves volatile oil component: Palmatic acid (棕欄 酸) 6.6%
Oridinin (冬凌草甲素, 延命草寧)
Five other ingredients of unknown structures
Roots, stems and leaves: trace minerals including iron, zinc（鋅）, manganese（錳）, copper（銅）, chromium（鉻）, nickel（鎳）, cobalt（鈷）, molybdenum（鉬）, selenium（硒） etc.

Name: zi ran
cumin
Common: French: cumin; cumin blanc; cumin du Maroc; faux anis
German: Kreuzk�mmel; Wei絽r Kreuzk�mmel; R闣ischer K�mmel; Mutterk�mmel

Maladies Treated: Fungal infection of the digestive tract (fruit)
Medical Function: Regulates qi and opens the stomach/appetite
Dosage:
Internal: decoction 3–9 g.
External: use appropriate amount; grind into powder, make into paste, and apply.
Contraindications:
Use with care in yinxu with fire, constipation, or hemorrhoids.

May increase the risk of bleeding when taken with blood-thinning drugs such as aspirin, warfarin (Coumadin) or heparin.

Use with caution with anti-platelet drugs such as clopidogrel (Plavix), and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen (Motrin, Advil) or naproxen (Naprosyn, Aleve).

May reduce blood sugar levels. Use with caution with medications that may also lower blood sugar; monitor closely and adjust diabetes medication as necessary.

May lower cholesterol. Caution with medications that also lower cholesterol; monitor and adjust as necessary.

May interact with narcotic pain relievers, antibiotics, anti-fungal drugs, and drugs that affect hormones.
Research:
In one study of Chinese cumin seeds, essential oil content was 3.8%. Of the oil, 97.97% comprised major components: cuminal (36.31%), cuminic alcohol (16.92%), γ-terpinene (11.14%), safranal (10.87%), p-cymene (9.85%), and β-pinene (7.75%). [1]

Anti-fungal effect. [2]

Contraceptive effect in male rats. [3]
Chemical Ingredients: Seed fats include: small amount of △5,6-octadecenoic acid
Seed crude protein contains 18 amino acids, including 8 essential amino acids
Elements: potassium, sodium, chlorine, iron, manganese, chromium, rubidium, bromine, copper, nickel, cobalt, aluminum, barium, lithium, silicon, titanium
References: 《Zhong Hua Materia Medica 中華本草 》

Name: e zhu
Biological: Curcuma kwangsiensis S. G. Lee et C. F. Liang (廣西莪朮)
Common: Urdu (Pakistan and certain part of India): kachoor

Geography: Guangxi e zhu (Curcuma kwangsiensis S. G. Lee et C. F. Liang) mainly produced in Guangxi.
Wen e zhu (Curcuma phaeocaulis Valeton) mainly produced in Zhejiang, Sichuan, Taiwan, Jiangxi.
Maladies Treated: Amenorrhea due to blood stasis (瘀血經閉)
Abdominal distension and pain due to stagnation of undigested food (食積脹痛)
Concretions, conglomerations, focal distention, and hard masses (癥瘕痞塊)
Early stages of cancer in the cervix uteri (early cervical cancer) (早期子宮頸癌)
Cancer of the neck of uterus (子宮頸癌)
Enlargement of liver and spleen (肝脾腫大)
Medical Function: Inhibits platelet coagulation (抗血小板凝集)
Improves immune system (增强免疫系统)
Improves circulation in the arteries in the thighs
Relieves pain; vinegar-processed e zhu increases the pain-relieving effect (止痛，尤其醋制能增加止痛之功)
Prevention of leukopenia (抗白血球减少症)
Promotes qi flow and breaks up blood stasis (行氣破血)
Disperses accumulations and stops pain (消積止痛)
Contraindications: Use care in cases of blood deficiency (xuexu) with qi deficiency (qixu) or spleen deficiency (pixu) without accumulation/stagnation (無積滯). Not to use during pregnancy or in cases of excessive menstrual bleeding (月經過多及孕婦忌服).
Research:
Memory improvement: [1] Zhong Yao Cai. 1998 Oct; 21(10): 522-3.
See on memory improvement in another site.
Notes: See the differentiating jiang huang (姜黄), yu jin (鬱金), shu gu jiang huang (束骨姜黄), and e zhu (莪朮).
Chemical Ingredients: Essential oil (1–1.5%): composed of multiple sesquiterpene derivatives and eucalyptol (桉油精); main ingredient: curzerenone (莪朮酮).

Properties: Acrid, cool (sheng jiang pi, fresh ginger skin)
Maladies Treated: Sheng jiang (fresh ginger): exterior cold with nasal congestion; warms the middle burner (jiao) and alleviates stuffy nose.
Sheng jiang (fresh ginger): intestinal hernia pain (xian qi of the Small Intestine).
Sheng jiang (fresh ginger): coughing due to chronic Lung deficiency with phlegm.
Sheng jiang (fresh ginger): mouth and tongue sores.
Sheng jiang (fresh ginger): axillary body odor (armpit odor).
Gan jiang (dry ginger): yang deficiency (yangxu) with cold in the middle; warms the middle, disperses cold, restores yang, unblocks the vessels.
Gan jiang (dry ginger): cold pain of chest and abdomen; low back pain.
Gan jiang (dry ginger): rebellious Stomach qi with dry retching (fan wei, gan ou).
Gan jiang (dry ginger): blood stasis (yu xue).
Pao jiang / hei jiang (baked/roasted ginger): warming the digestive system, getting rid of heat due to deficiency
Pao jiang / hei jiang (baked/roasted ginger): cold pain of chest and abdomen; abdominal distension/flatulence (zhang man).
Pao jiang / hei jiang (baked/roasted ginger): diarrhea, dysentery (xia li), cholera (huo luan).

Pao jiang / hei jiang (baked/roasted ginger): bleeding disorders—stops bleeding, removes congealed blood; hematemesis (vomiting blood); blood dysentery; excessive uterine bleeding/menorrhagia and metrorrhagia (崩漏).
Sheng jiang pi (fresh ginger skin): edema; difficulty in urination; taken as decoction.
Medical Function: Reduces the toxicity of other herbs such as fu zi (Aconite, 附子) and ban xia (Pinellia, 半夏).
Anti-inflammatory: can block the effects of prostaglandins that may cause inflammation of blood vessels in the brain and lead to headache.
Anti–hair growth (external use): 6-gingerol identified as the active constituent with hair-growth suppressive potential.
Gastrointestinal: gingerol inhibits abnormal fermentation in the intestine and helps expel gas; anti–peptic ulcer.
Protects the liver; cardiac stimulation; improves auto-immune function.
Antimicrobial: antibiotic (especially Salmonella); antibacterial; anti-trichomoniasis; antiparasitic.
Dosage:
Fresh ginger (sheng jiang): 3–8 grams per day in decoction.
Dry ginger (gan jiang): 1–3 grams per day, in powder form. (Chinese text states: 每日 3 克。作粉劑。)
Fresh ginger skin (sheng jiang pi): 3–10 grams per day in decoction.
Samples of Formulae:
Sheng jiang (fresh ginger): gui zhi tang; ma huang tang; huang qi gui zhi wu wu tang; gui pi tang; wen dan fang.

Hei jiang / pao jiang (baked/roasted ginger): sheng hua tang; huang qi gui zhi wu wu tang.

Gan jiang (dry ginger): li zhong tang.
Contraindications: Do not use in cases of yin deficiency with internal heat (yinxu) or in excess heat patterns, or in Stomach heat with vomiting.
Research:
Gingerol content decreases after processing and storage of ginger. [1]

Effect on E. coli: zingerone significantly blocked the binding of enterotoxin to the cell-surface receptor GM1, resulting in inhibition of fluid accumulation in closed ileal loops of mice, thus preventing diarrhea. [2]

Prevents dropping of fibrinolytic activity from eating fatty meals. [3]

Anti–hair growth: 6-gingerol suppressed human hair growth via inhibitory and pro-apoptotic effects on dermal papilla cells in vitro and caused prolongation of the telogen phase in vivo; suggests potential as a hair growth suppressive agent. [5]

Hepatoprotection: protects liver cells from damage by CCl4.
Notes: Fibrinolysis is a process that prevents blood clots from growing and becoming problematic.

Name: qiang huo
羌活
Botanical: Notopterygium incisum Ting ex HT Chang
Other name: gou yin zi hua 狗引子花

Maladies Treated: common cold due to wind-cold with aversion to cold and fever (感冒風寒、惡寒發熱)
bi pain due to wind-dampness (風濕痹痛)
Medical Function: improves volume of nutritional blood circulation
Expels wind and releases the exterior (袪風解表)
Samples of Formulae: qiang huo sheng shi tang (羌活勝濕湯).
Contraindications: Contraindicated in cases of numbness and pain with xue xu (blood deficiency) or with yinxu (yin deficiency). Overdose may cause nausea and vomitting.
References: [n] 中藥現代研究與臨床引用，陰健，郭力弓。羌活。
